definition[0]: during the time that something is happening
example[0]: They arrived while we were having dinner.
example[1]: While she was asleep, thieves broke in and stole her handbag.
example[2]: She met Andy while working on a production of ‘Carmen’.
definition[1]: all the time that something is happening
example[3]: Would you look after the children while I do the shopping?
explanation[0]: You use the present tense, not ‘will’, with while when you are talking about the future
example[4]: I hope to visit the British Museum while I am in London
bad_example[0]: I hope to visit the British Museum while I will be in London
definition[2]: used to emphasize the difference between two situations, activities etc
example[5]: Schools in the north tend to be better equipped, while those in the south are relatively poor.
definition[3]: in spite of the fact that
example[6]: While never a big eater, he did snack a lot.
example[7]: While there was no conclusive evidence, most people thought he was guilty.
definition[4]: during the time that you are doing something, or something is happening
example[8]: I bought a magazine while I was waiting for the train.
example[9]: While we were on holiday, my bag was stolen.
definition[5]: at the same time as something else is happening
example[10]: They’re still working on our bedroom. Meanwhile, we’re sleeping downstairs.
example[11]: The Russians, meanwhile, declared war on August 8.
definition[6]: during the period of time between now and a future event, or between two events in the past
example[12]: More aid is expected soon, but in the meantime these people are going hungry.
example[13]: My new job hadn’t started, so in the meantime I tried to write a book.
definition[7]: while. Whilst sounds a little more formal than while
example[14]: One American plane was forced to land whilst flying over North Korea.
example[15]: Whilst all this was going on, the performers were getting ready for the show.
